content.description:
This route climbs the right of two cracks located about 15 feet right of "

Anything but the Fast Lane

."  Most of the climbing is about 5.6ish.  There is a bush about 8 feet up on the start that you must go around to the left.  At the top of the cracks, you will have to move diagonally up and left for 20 feet, then finish the route with a traverse left for 10 feet to the anchor for

Anything but the Fast Lane

.

The route is dirty -- someone must have been climbed it before but not recently.  I saw the crack and started up it, because it looked like an easy layback, knowing it was not in my guidebook -- but I also thought I saw black anchor chains at the top of the left crack.  When I got up there, it was not anchor chains -- it was bird poop!  So, I had to traverse up and about 25 feet left to get to the anchors for

Anything but the Fast Lane

.  The hardest part of the climb was probably the 10 feet of left horizontal traverse to the anchors.
content.protection: I place about three cams in the cracks from BD #1 to a #4, then a few more cams from a 0.3 to a #1 on the diagonalling left traverse.
content.location:
This is two obvious cracks about 15 feet right of "

Anything but the Fast Lane

."  The left crack is fairly wide, and the right crack looks like it's good for a layback.  There's a bush about 8 feet off the ground on a small ledge in the right crack.  You may have to do a little gardening in both cracks.

climbs.name: Third World Cantina
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton, Stewart Green, Autumn Thorpe, and CJ Sidebottom, March 2005

content.description: Start right of a fir tree (the fir tree is actually touching the rock). Mantle up and face climb through some friable rock. Follow a bolt line up to the roof. Watch for birds and "what have yous" in the crack that is under the roof. Clip a bolt that is at the roof and pull up and over. There is a bolt that is back about 2 feet from the roof as you pull over. Take a #1 and #2 Camalot to use in the hand crack above the roof that you will move though to get to the anchors.
content.protection: 6 quickdraws and #1 and #2 Camalots. Bring something for the 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Look for the fir tree that is abutting the rock. The route starts to the right of this tree.

climbs.name: My Next 30 Years
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton and Stewart Green, February 2005

content.description:
Start up the short groove (hand jams), avoiding a dodgy block, then move easily left to the base of the open corner.  This is easy to begin with, but the crack at the back is less helpful higher up - bridge to the little overlap at the top of the corner then step right on to a slab.  Move 10' right to bolts at the top of

Down the Allie

.
content.protection: Nuts and cams: small cams are useful on the crux.
content.location: At the far left of Back Street Wall are a couple of 15' high grooves at ground level.  This route starts up the lefthand one and aims for an obvious dihedral higher up.

climbs.name: Get High Street
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton and Stewart Green, March 2005

content.description:
This route is immediately to the left of

Anything But The Fast Lane

. I believe the crux is just getting started on the route. Right off the deck you move through a bulge/roof. There is a great hand jam if you can reach it. The start is easier if you are taller. Pull through the roof and climb up and left past horizontal cracks. The bottom of the route takes gear and the upper half of the route has 3 bolts to a two bolt anchor. This route finishes and the same anchors as

Anything But The Fast Lane

.
content.protection: Bring small to medium cams up to #2 Camalot and quickdraws for the bolts. You can get off with a 60m.
content.location:
This is immediately to the left of the route

Anything But The Fast Lane

.

climbs.name: Down the Allie
climbs.fa: Stewart Green, Mike Heinrichs, and Allie AKA Sherry Heinrichs, January 2005

content.description:
Start up a short groove, then climb easily left up cracks.  Move up right to reach the base of a short overhung slot with a crack at the back.  Go up this (crux), then pull out on good jams, and follow easier cracks to bolt belays.

It is generally straightforward with a short, awkward crux.
content.location: At the far left of Back Street Wall are a couple of 15' high grooves at ground level.  This route starts up the righthand one and aims for a short slot higher up.

climbs.name: Anything But The Fast Lane
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton, Stewart Green, and Tor Morris-Ballasy, February 2005

content.description: This route starts behind a large pine tree. Pull up and over a roof and work up cracks that are discontinuous. The route moves up and to the left to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Small stoppers and and small to medium cams from blue Alien up to #3 Camalot. You can place a #3 Camalot right off the deck. Bring a few slings to keep the rope running fairly straight. We used a 70m rope, but I'm pretty sure you can get off with a 60m.
content.location:
This starts just behind a tree and to the right of

Get High Street

.

climbs.name: A-Frame (aka A Street)
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton, Stewart Green, and Mike Heinrichs, March 2005.

content.description: This is a great crack!  Climb up the low-angle slab to the dihedral.  Work the steep crack on fingers, hands, and stems.  Clip the lone bolt and pull over the top.  The run to the anchor is on easy, low-angle slab below the big roof.  Crack ratings are always subjective; if you have fat hands and fat fingers like me, youll find perfect jams along the way, making this route a bit easier than the rating.  Rappel to descend.
content.protection: Gear to 4 or 5 plus one bolt, bolted anchor.
content.location:
This is the obvious dihedral 20 to the right of

Third World Cantina

.
